subject: Call of Cthulhu: 1 or 3 typos, depending on [n] vs. [N]
msgSnippet: I wanted to mention that I ve changed  s  to  stricken  in paragraph 3. I also was planning on changing  concluded and inclined to use NO instead of
messageBody:
I wanted to mention that I've changed " s " to " stricken " in paragraph 3.

I also was planning on changing "concluded" and "inclined" to use NO instead of INK, but I wanted to check in with others first — is there a systematic preference for [N] over [n] in places that I'm not hearing?

Also, since we're talking about [N], why does Read seem to prefer [IN] instead of [iN] for -ing? Is this happy-tensing at work again, or a different shift?

(incidentally, I am transferring these explanations elsewhere — once I'm not bumping into differences between Read's RP and contemporary Southern Californian on a regular basis, I'll put "Why Can't Kingsley Read Spell.markdown" on the Interwebs somewhere.)
